projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A Treaty Marine Between The Mo≈øt Serene and Mighty PRINCE CHARLES II. By the Grace of God King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.

And the High and Mighty LORDS THE STATES GENERAL OF THE UNITED NETHERLANDS, To be ob≈øerved throughout all and every the Countreys and Parts of the World by Sea and Land, Concluded at London the Fir≈øt day of December 1674. S. V.
LONDON, Printed by the A≈ø≈øigns of John Bill and Chri≈øtopher Barker, Printers to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty. 1674.

div.head: Artic. I.
div.p:
THAT it ≈øhall and may be lawful, for all and every the Subjects of the Mo≈øt Serene and Mighty Prince, the King of Great Britain afore≈øaid, with all Freedom and Safety to Sail, Trade, and Exerci≈øe any manner of Traffique, in all tho≈øe Kingdoms, Countreys, and E≈øtates, which are, or at any time hereafter ≈øhall be in Peace, Amity, or Neutrality with His ≈øaid Maje≈øty; So that they ≈øhall not be any ways hindred or mole≈øted in their Navigation or Trade, by the Military Forces, nor by the Ships of War, or any other kind of Ve≈ø≈øels what≈øoever, belonging either to the High and
Mighty States General of the United Netherlands, or to their Subjects, upon Occa≈øion or Pretence of any Ho≈øtility or Difference which now is, or ≈øhall hereafter happen between the ≈øaid Lords the States General, and any Princes or People what≈øoever, in Peace, Amity, or Neutrality with His ≈øaid Maje≈øty: And likewi≈øe, that it ≈øhall and may be lawful for all and every the Subjects of the ≈øaid High and Mighty Lords the States General of the United Netherlands, with all Freedom and Safety to Sail, Trade, and Exerci≈øe any manner of Traffique in all tho≈øe Kingdoms, Countreys and E≈øtates, which are, or at any time hereafter ≈øhall be in Peace, Amity, or Neutrality with the afore≈øaid Lords the States; So that they ≈øhall not be any ways hindred or mole≈øted in their Navigation or Trade, by the Military Forces, nor by the Ships of War, or any other kind of Ve≈ø≈øels what≈øoever, belonging either to the Mo≈øt Serene and Mighty King above mentioned, or to His Subjects, upon Occa≈øion or Pretence of any Ho≈øtility or Difference, which
now is, or ≈øhall hereafter happen between His ≈øaid Maje≈øty, and any Princes or People what≈øoever, in Peace, Amity, or Neutrality with the ≈øaid Lords the States.

div.head: II.
div.p: Nor ≈øhall this Freedom of Navigation and Commerce be infringed, by Occa≈øion or Cau≈øe of any War, in any kind of Merchandizes; but ≈øhall Extend to all Commodities which ≈øhall be carried in time of Peace; tho≈øe onely Excepted which follow in the next Article, and are Comprehended under the Name of Contraband.

div.head: III.
div.p:
Under this name of Contraband or Prohibited Merchandizes, ≈øhall be comprehended onely Arms, Pieces of Ordnance, with all Implements belonging to them, Fireballs, Powder, Match, Bullets, Pikes, Swords, Lances, Spears, Halberds, Guns, Mortar-piedes, Petards, Granadoes, Mu≈øket-re≈øts,
Bandeliers, Salt-peter, Muskets, Musket-≈øhot, Helmets, Cor≈ølets, Brea≈øt-plates, Coats of Mail, and the like kind of Armature, Soldiers, Hor≈øes, and all things nece≈ø≈øary for the Furniture of Hor≈øes, Hol≈øters, Belts, and all other Warlike In≈øtruments what≈øoever.

div.head: IV.
div.p:
The≈øe Merchandizes following ≈øhall not be reckoned among Prohibited Goods, viz. all kind of Cloth; and all other Manufactures Woven of any kind of Wooll, Flax, Silk, Cotton, or any other Material; all ≈øorts of Clothing and Ve≈øtments, together with the Materials whereof they u≈øe to be made; Gold and Silver, as well Coyned as not Coyned; Tin, Iron, Lead, Copper, and Coles; as al≈øo Wheat, Barley, and all other kind of Corn or Pul≈øe; Tobacco, and all kind of Spices, Salted and Smoked Fle≈øh, Salted and Dried Fi≈øh, Butter and Chee≈øe, Beer, Oyls, Wines, Sugars, and all ≈øort of Salt; and in general,
all Provi≈øion which ≈øerves for the Nouri≈øhment and Su≈øtenance of Life; likewi≈øe all kind of Cotton, Hemp, Flax and Pitch; and Ropes, Sails and Anchors; al≈øo Ma≈øts and Planks, Boards and Beams of what ≈øort of Wood ≈øoever, and all other Materials requi≈øite for the Building or Repairing Ships, but they ≈øhall be wholly reputed among≈øt Free Goods, even as all other Wares and Commodities which are not comprehended in the next precedent Article; So that the ≈øame may be freely Tran≈øported and Carried by the Subjects of His ≈øaid Maje≈øty, even unto Places in Enmity with the ≈øaid States, as al≈øo on the other ≈øide, by the Subjects of the ≈øaid States, to Places under the Obedience of the Enemies of His ≈øaid Maje≈øty; Except onely Towns or Places Be≈øieged, Environed, or Inve≈øted, in French Bloc quees ou inve≈øties.

div.head: V.
div.p:
And that all manner of Differences and Contentions on both ≈øides by Sea and Land,
may from he ceforth Cea≈øe and be utterly Extingui≈øhed, It is agreed, That all kind of Ships and Ve≈ø≈øels what≈øoever, belonging to the Subjects of His ≈øaid Maje≈øty, entring or being entred into any Road or Port under the Obedience of the Lords the States, and purpo≈øing to pa≈øs from thence, ≈øhall be onely obliged to ≈øhew unto the Officers acting in the Ports of the ≈øaid States, or to the Captains of the States Ships, or of Private men of War (if any happen there to be) their Pa≈øsport, commonly called a Seabrief (the form whereof is added at the end of the≈øe Articles;) nor ≈øhall any money or any thing el≈øe be exacted f om them under that Pretence; But if any Ship belonging to the Subjects of His Maje≈øty of Great Britain, ≈øhall in the open Sea; or el≈øewhere, out of the Dominions of the ≈øaid States, meet the Ships of War of the ≈øaid Lords the States, or Private men of War of their Subjects, the ≈øaid Ships of the Lords the States, or of their Subjects, ≈øhall keep at a convenient di≈øtance, and onely ≈øend out their Boat, and it ≈øhall be lawful for them
onely with two or three men, to go on Board the Ships and Ve≈ø≈øels of the Subjects of His Maje≈øty, that the Pa≈ø≈øeport (or Seabrief) of the propriety thereof according to the Form hereafter Specified, may be ≈øhewen to them by the Captain or Ma≈øter of ≈øuch Ship or Ve≈ø≈øel belonging to the Subjects of His Maje≈øty; and the Ship which ≈øhall ≈øhew the ≈øame ≈øhall freely pa≈øs, and it ≈øhall not be lawful to Mole≈øt, Search, Detain, or Divert the ≈øame from her intended Voyage: And all the Subjects of the Lords the States ≈øhall enjoy in all things, the ≈øame Liberty and Immunity, they in like manner ≈øhewing their Pa≈ø≈øeport (or Sea-brief) made according to the Form Pre≈øcribed at the latter end of this Treaty.

div.head: VI.
div.p:
But if any Ship or Ve≈ø≈øel belonging to the Engli≈øh or other Subjects of His Maje≈øty, ≈øhall be met making into any Port in Enmity with the Lords the States; Or on the other ≈øide, if any Ship belonging to the
United Provinces of the Netherlands, or other Subjects of the Lords the States, ≈øhall be met in her way making into any Port under the Obedience of the Enemies of His ≈øaid Maje≈øty, ≈øuch Ship ≈øhall ≈øhew, not onely a Pa≈ø≈øeport (or Sea-brief) according to the Form here under Pre≈øcribed, wherewith ≈øhe is to be Furni≈øhed, but al≈øo her Cocquets expre≈ø≈øing the Contents of the Goods on Board, given in the u≈øual Form, by the Officers of the Cu≈øtoms in the Port from whence ≈øhe came, whereby it may be known whether ≈øhe is Laden with any Merchandizes Prohibited by the Third Article of this Treaty.

div.head: VII.
div.p:
But if by the ≈øhewing the above≈øaid Cocquets expre≈ø≈øing the Contents of the Goods on Board, given in the u≈øual Form by the Officers of the Cu≈øtoms in the Port from whence ≈øhe came, (concerning the ≈øhewing whereof it is above agreed) either Party ≈øhall Di≈øcover any kind of Merchandizes, which in the Third Article of this Treaty
are declared to be Contraband or Prohibited, Con≈øigned to any Port under the Obedience of their Enemies, it ≈øhall not be lawful to open the Hatches of ≈øuch Ship, in which the ≈øame ≈øhall happen to be found, whether ≈øhe belongs to the Subjects of His Maje≈øty, or of the Lords the States; nor to Unlock, or Break open the Che≈øts, Males, Packs, or Casks in the ≈øame, nor to Convey away any the lea≈øt part of the Merchandizes, before the whole be fir≈øt Landed in the Pre≈øence of the Officers of the Admiralty, and Inventaried; neither ≈øhall it be any ways lawful to Sell, Exchange, or otherwi≈øe to Alienate the ≈øame, until ≈øuch Prohibited Goods are rightly and lawfully Proceeded again≈øt, and that the Judges of the Admiralty, have by their re≈øpective Sentences Confi≈øcated the ≈øame: Provided always, That as well the Ship it ≈øelf, as the re≈øt of the Commodities found in the ≈øame, which by this Treaty are to be reputed Free, ≈øhall not upon pretence of their being infected by ≈øuch Prohibited Goods, be Detained, much le≈øs Confi≈øcated for lawful Prize; But if
not the whole, but a part onely of the Lading Con≈øi≈øts of Contraband or Prohibited Commodities, and that the Ma≈øter of the Ship ≈øhall be willing and ready to Deliver them to the Captor who Seized the ≈øame, in that ca≈øe the Captor ≈øhall not Compel the Ship to go out of her Cour≈øe, to any Port he thinks fit, but ≈øhall forthwith Di≈ømi≈øs her, and upon no Accompt hinder her from freely pro≈øecuting her De≈øigned Voyage.

div.head: VIII.
div.p:
It is further Agreed, That what≈øoever ≈øhall be found Laden by His Maje≈øties Subjects, upon any Ship what≈øoever belonging to the Enemies of the Lords the States, although the ≈øame be not of the quality of Contraband Goods, may be Confi≈øcated; But on the contrary, all that which ≈øhall be found in the Ships belonging to the Subjects of His Maje≈øty, ≈øhall be accounted Clear and Free, although the whole Lading or any part thereof, by ju≈øt Title of Propriety,
≈øhall belong to the Enemies of the Lords the States; Except always Contraband Goods, which being intercepted, all things ≈øhall be done according to the Meaning and and Direction of the Precedent Articles; And by the ≈øame rea≈øon, what≈øoever ≈øhall be found Laden by the Subjects of the Lords the States, in any Ship what≈øoever belonging to the Enemies of His Maje≈øty, although the ≈øame be not of the quality of Contraband Goods, may be Confi≈øcated; But on the other ≈øide, all that which ≈øhall be found in the Ships belonging to the Subjects of the Lords the States, ≈øhall be accounted Clear and Free, although the whole Lading, or any part thereof, by ju≈øt Title of Propriety, ≈øhall belong to the Enemies of His Maje≈øty; Except always Contraband Goods, which being Intercepted, all things ≈øhall be done according to the Meaning and Direction of the Precedent Articles. And lea≈øt any Damage ≈øhould by Surprize, be done to the one Party who is in Peace, when the other Party ≈øhall happen to be Engaged in War, It is Provided and Agreed, That a
Ship belonging to the Enemies of the one Party, and Laden with Goods of the Subjects of the other Party, ≈øhall not infect or render the ≈øaid Goods liable to Confi≈øcation, in ca≈øe they were Laden before the Expiration of the Terms and Times hereafter mantioned, after the Declaration, or Publication of any ≈øuch War; viz. If the Goods were Laden in any Port or Place between the Places or Limits called the Soundings, and the Naz in Norway, within the ≈øpace of Six weeks after ≈øuch Declaration; Of two Moneths between the ≈øaid Place the Soundings, and the City of Tangier; and of Ten weeks in the Mediterranean Sea; Or within the ≈øpace of Eight Moneths, in any other Country or Place of the World; So that it ≈øhall not be lawful to Confi≈øcate the Goods of the Subjects of His Maje≈øty taken or ≈øeized in any Ship or Ve≈ø≈øel what≈øoever of any Enemy of the Lords the States, upon that Pretence, but the ≈øame ≈øhall be without delay Re≈øtored to the Proprietors, unle≈øs they were Laden after the Expiration of the ≈øaid Terms of Time re≈øpectively; but ≈øo that it
may not be lawful for them afterwards to Carry to Enemies Ports, the ≈øaid Merchandizes which are called Contraband, and for the rea≈øon afore≈øaid ≈øhall not be liable to Confi≈øcation; Neither on the other ≈øide, ≈øhall it be lawful to Confi≈øcate the Goods of the Subjects of the Lords the States taken or ≈øeized in any Ship or Ve≈ø≈øel what≈øoever of an Enemy of His Maje≈øty, upon that Pretence; but the ≈øame ≈øhall be forthwith Re≈øtored to the Proprietors thereof, unle≈øs they were Laden after the expiration of the ≈øaid Terms of Time re≈øpectively; But ≈øo, that it may not be lawful for them afterwards to Carry to Enemies Ports, the ≈øaid Merchandizes which are called Contraband, and for the rea≈øon afore≈øaid ≈øhall not be liable to Confi≈øcation.

div.head: IX.
div.p:
And the more to a≈ø≈øure the Subjects of His Maje≈øty and of the ≈øaid States, that no Injury ≈øhall be offered to them by the Ships of War, or Private men of War of either ≈øide, all the Captains of the Ships, as well of His
Maje≈øty, as of the ≈øaid States, and all their Subjects who ≈øhall ≈øet out Private men of War, and likewi≈øe their Priviledged Companies, ≈øhall be enjoyned not to do any Injury or Damage what≈øoever, to the other; which if they do, they ≈øhall be puni≈øhed, and moreover be liable to ≈øatisfie all Co≈øts and Damages, by Re≈øtitution and Reparation, upon Pain and Obligation of Per≈øon and Goods.

div.head: X.
div.p:
For this cau≈øe all the Commanders of Private men of War, ≈øhall from henceforth be Obliged before they Receive their Commi≈ø≈øions, to Enter before a Competent Judge, Good and Sufficient Security by Able and Re≈øpon≈øible men, who have no Part or Intere≈øt in ≈øuch Ship, in the Sum of Fifteen hundred pounds Sterling, or Sixteen thou≈øand five hundred Gilders; and when they have above One hundred and fifty men, then in the Sum of Three thou≈øand pounds Sterling, or Three and thirty
thou≈øand Gilders, that they will give full Satisfaction for any Damages or Injuries what≈øoever, which they or their Officers, or others in their Service ≈øhall Commit in their Cour≈øes at Sea, contrary to this Pre≈øent Treaty, or any Other what≈øoever, between His Maje≈øty and the ≈øaid States, and upon pain of Revocation and Annulling their ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øions, in which it ≈øhall be always In≈øerted, that they have given ≈øuch Security as above≈øaid; And likewi≈øe, it is Agreed, That the Ship it ≈øelf ≈øhall be al≈øo liable to make Satisfaction for Injuries and Damages done by her.

div.head: XI.
div.p:
His Maje≈øty, and the ≈øaid States being De≈øirous that the Subjects of each other may be mutually Treated in all Countreys under their Obedience re≈øpectively, with the like kindne≈øs as their own Subjects, will give all nece≈ø≈øary and effectual Orders, that Judgments upon Prizes Taken, be given according to the Rule of Ju≈øtice,
and Equity, by Judges beyond all ≈øu≈øpition, and not any way concerned in the Cau≈øe under Debate; And His Maje≈øty, and the ≈øaid States will likewi≈øe give ≈øtrict Orders that all Sentences already given, and which ≈øhall be hereafter given, be (according to the Tenor thereof) duly put in Execution, and obtain their Effect.

div.head: XII.
div.p:
And when≈øoever the Amba≈ø≈øadors of the ≈øaid Lords the States, or any other their Publick Mini≈øters, Re≈øident at the Court of His Mo≈øt Serene Maje≈øty of Great Britain, ≈øhall complain of the unju≈øtne≈øs of Sentences which have been given, His Maje≈øty will cau≈øe the ≈øame to be Reviewed and Examined in His Council, that it may appear whether the Orders and Praecautions Pre≈øcribed in this Treaty, have been Ob≈øerved, and have had their due Effect, and will al≈øo take care that the ≈øame be fully provided for, and that Right be done to the Party complaining, within the ≈øpace
of Three Moneths; And likewi≈øe when the Amba≈ø≈øadors, or other Publick Mini≈øters of His Maje≈øty, Re≈øident with the Sates General, ≈øhall complain of the unju≈øtne≈øs of Sentences, the ≈øaid States will cau≈øe a Review and Examination thereof to be made in the A≈ø≈øembly of the States General, that it may appear whether the Orders and Praecautions Pre≈øcribed in this Treaty have been Ob≈øerved, and have had their due Effect, and they will likewi≈øe take care that the ≈øame be fully provided for, and that Right be done to the Party complaining, within the ≈øpace of Three Moneths: Neverthele≈øs it ≈øhall not any ways be lawful to Sell or Unlade the Goods in Controver≈øie, either before the Sentence given, or after it, during the Review thereof, on either ≈øide, unle≈øs it be with the con≈øent of the Parties Intere≈ø≈øed.

div.head: XIII.
div.p:
A Suit being Commenced between the Takers of Prizes on the one Part, and
the Claimers thereof on the other, and a Sentence or Decree being given for the Party Reclaiming, the ≈øaid Sentence or Decree (upon Security given) ≈øhall be put in Execution, notwith≈øtanding the Appeal made by him that took the Prize, which ≈øhall not be Ob≈øerved, in ca≈øe the Sentence ≈øhall be given again≈øt the Claimers.

div.head: XIV.
div.p:
And whereas the Ma≈øters of Merchants Ships, and likewi≈øe the Mariners and Pa≈ø≈øengers, do ≈øometimes ≈øuffer many Cruelties and Barbarous u≈øages, when they are brought under the Power of Ships which take Prizes in time of War, the Takers in an inhumane manner Tormenting them, thereby to Extort from them ≈øuch Confe≈ø≈øions as they would have to be made, It is Agreed, that both His Maje≈øty, and the Lords the States General, ≈øhall by the Severe≈øt Proclamations or Placaets, forbid all ≈øuch Hainous and Inhumane Offences,
and as many as they ≈øhall by lawful Proofs find Guilty of ≈øuch Acts, they ≈øhall take Care that they be Puni≈øhed with due and ju≈øt Puni≈øhments, and which may be a Terror to others; And ≈øhall Command that all the Captains and Officers of Ships, who ≈øhall be proved to have Committed ≈øuch Hainous Practi≈øes, either them≈øelves or by In≈øtigating others to Act the ≈øame, or by Conniving while they were done, ≈øhall (be≈øides other Puni≈øhments to be Inflicted proportionably to their Offences) be forthwith deprived of their Offices re≈øpectively; And every Ship brought up as Prize, who≈øe Mariners or Pa≈ø≈øengers ≈øhall have ≈øuffered any Torture, ≈øhall forthwith be Di≈ømi≈ø≈øed and Freed, with all her Lading, from all further Examination and Proceedings, again≈øt her, as well judicial as otherwi≈øe.

div.head: XV.
div.p: It is al≈øo Agreed, That the like Severity of Puni≈øhments ≈øhall be inflicted upon tho≈øe, who contrary to the meaning of the One and twentieth Article of the Treaty of Peace Concluded at Breda, ≈øhall take Commi≈ø≈øions from Enemies, to Seize the Ships of either Ally (or party) contrary to what is Provided in the ≈øaid Article.

div.head: XVI.
div.p:
La≈øtly, It is Agreed and Concluded that this pre≈øent Treaty and all and ≈øingular the things therein Contained, ≈øhall be with all convenient ≈øpeed on both ≈øides Ratified and Confirmed, and that the Ratifications thereof ≈øhall be within two Moneths from the Date hereof, Rightly and Reciprocally Exchanged between both Parties; And al≈øo that the ≈øaid Treaty ≈øhall within one Moneth after ≈øuch Exchanging of the Ratifications, be Delivered in Due and Authentique
Form to the Governours of the Engli≈øh East-India and Affrica Companies, and to the Directors of the Dutch East and West-India Companies, and ≈øhall with the fir≈øt Conveniency be al≈øo Sent by His ≈øaid Maje≈øty, and by the ≈øaid Lords the States, to their re≈øpective Governours and Commanders in Chief of their Colonies and Plantations in every part of the World out of Europe, to the end that it may be by them, and all others within their Dominions and under their Power, punctually Ob≈øerved and Fulfilled.

div.head: The Form of the Pa≈øsport (or Sea-brief) to be asked of, and given by the Lord High Admiral, or by tho≈øe to whom the Exerci≈øe of Admiralty-Juri≈ødiction is ordinarily Committed, or by the Mayor, or other Chief Magi≈øtrate, or by the Commi≈ø≈øioners, or other Principal Officers of the Cu≈øtoms in their re≈øpective Ports and Places within His Maje≈øties Dominions, to the Ships and Ve≈ø≈øels Sailing out thence, according to the Purport of the Fifth Article.
div.p:
TO all unto whom the≈øe Pre≈øents ≈øhall come, Greeting. We _____ Lord High Admiral of _____ We _____ Lords Commi≈øsioners Executing the Office of the Lord High Admiral of _____
or We _____ Judge of the High Court of the Admiralty of _____ or We _____ the Mayor, or other Magi≈øtrate of _____ or We _____ Commi≈øsioners, or Principal Officers of the Cu≈øtoms in the City or Port of _____ Do Te≈øtifie and make Known, That _____ Ma≈øter or Commander of the Ship called the _____ hath appeared before ∆≤s, and hath Declared by Solemn Oath, That the ≈øaid Ship or Ve≈ø≈øel Containing about _____ Tons, of which he is at pre≈øent Ma≈øter or Commander, doth belong to the Inhabitants of _____ within the Dominions of the Mo≈øt Serene and Mighty Prince, the King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland,
Defender of the Faith, &c. So help him God. And in regard it would be mo≈øt acceptable to ∆≤s, that the ≈øaid Ma≈øter or Commander be A≈ø≈øi≈øted in his ju≈øt and lawful Affairs, We do Reque≈øt you, and every of you, where≈øoever the ≈øaid Ma≈øter or Commander ≈øhall Arrive with his Ship, and the Goods Laden on Board and Carried in her, that you would plea≈øe to Receive him Courteou≈øly and u≈øe him Kindly, and Admit him, upon Paying the lawful and u≈øual Cu≈øtoms and other Duties, to Enter into, Remain in, and Pa≈øs from your Ports, Rivers, and Dominions, and there to Enjoy all kind of Right of Navigation, Traffick, and Commerce, in all Places
where he ≈øhall think fit; Which We ≈øhall mo≈øt willingly and readily acknowledge upon all Occa≈øions: In Te≈øtimony and Confirmation whereof, We have with Our Hand Signed the≈øe Pre≈øents, and cau≈øed them to be Sealed with Our Seal: Dated at _____ in _____ the _____ day of _____ in the Year of Our Lord

div.head: The Form of the Pa≈øport (or Sea-brief) to be asked of, and given by the Burger-ma≈øters of the Cities and Ports of the United Netherlands, to the Ships or Ve≈ø≈øels Sailing from thence, according to the Purport of the Fifth Article.
div.p:
TO the most Serene, most Illustrious, mo≈øt Mighty, most Noble, most Honourable, and most Prudent Emperours, Kings, Governours of Common-wealths, Princes, Dukes, Earles, Barons, Lords, Burger-ma≈øters, Schepens, Coun≈øellors, Judges, Officers, Ju≈øtices, and Rulers of all Cities and Places as well Eccle≈øiastical as Secular, to whom the≈øe Pre≈øents ≈øhall be ≈øhewn; We the Burger-ma≈øters and Rulers of the City of _____ do Certifie, That _____ Ma≈øter or Skipper of the Ship _____ appeared before Us, and Declared by Solemn Oath, That the ≈øaid
Ship called the _____ containing about _____ La≈øts, of which he is at pre≈øent Ma≈øter or Skipper, belongeth to the Inhabitants of the United Netherlands: So help him God. And in regard it would be mo≈øt acceptable to Us, that the ≈øaid Ma≈øter or Skipper be A≈øsi≈øted in his ju≈øt and lawful Affairs, We do Reque≈øt you, and every of you, where≈øoever the ≈øaid Ma≈øter or Skipper ≈øhall Arrive with his Ship, and the Goods Laden on Board and Carried in her, that you would plea≈øe to Receive him courteou≈øly, and u≈øe him kindly, and admit him, upon paying the lawful and u≈øual Cu≈øtoms and other Duties, to Enter into; Remain in, and Pa≈øs from your Ports, Rivers, and Dominions, and there to enjoy all kind of Right of Navigation, Traffick, and Commerce, in all Places where he ≈øhall think fit; Which We ≈øhall most willingly and readily acknowledge upon all Occa≈øions: In Te≈øtimony and Confirmation whereof, We have cau≈øed the Seal of Our City to be hereunto put: Dated at _____ in _____ the _____ day of _____ in the year of Our Lord

In Te≈øtimony and Confirmation of all and ≈øingular the Premi≈øes, We the Commi≈ø≈øioners of His Maje≈øty, and the Lords the States General afore≈øaid, being ≈øufficiently Impower'd thereunto, have to the≈øe Pre≈øents Sub≈øcribed Our Names, and Sealed them with Our Seals, At London, the Fir≈øt day of December. 1674.
